metadata.case_name: M/s. Bhajan Singh Hardat Singh and Co. v. Karson Agency India and another
metadata.case_number: Letters Patent Appeal under Clause 10 of Letters Patent

facts.text: On 14-2-1951, respondents agreed at Delhi to purchase from appellant 500 yards of worsted woolen cloth of Indian Woolen Mills, steel colour, June-July Challan at Rs.23/4/- per yard and paid Rs.1,000/- as advance.

On 25-7-1951, appellant sent Bill Ex. P-10 No. 5306 for 500 yards worsted as per contract, requiring respondents to take delivery after payment of Rs.10,625/- (balance after advance) by end of July 1951.
Respondents did not take delivery of the goods by end of July 1951.

On 6-8-1951, appellant sent registered notice Ex. P-7 informing respondents to take delivery within 4 days against payment of Rs.10,625/- failing which goods would be sold at their risk and responsibility.
Respondents did not take delivery despite notice.
Appellant sold the goods on retail basis on 8-11-1951, 9-11-1951, 10-11-1951, 15-11-1951, 16-11-1951 and 20-11-1951 at prevailing market rates, realising Rs.7,349/1/9.
Contract price Rs.11,625/-, resale realised Rs.7,349/1/9, loss Rs.4,392/9/6, after adjusting advance Rs.1,000/-, balance due Rs.3,392/9/6.
Suit No. 718 of 1954 filed on 19-11-1954 for recovery of Rs.3,392/9/6 with future interest at 10 annas per cent per mensem from date of decree.
Trial Court (Sub-Judge, Delhi) by judgment dated 1-11-1955 held suit within time, decreed as prayed.
First Appeal No. 43 of 1956 dismissed by Additional District Judge, Delhi on 8/9-4-1957, affirmed suit not barred.
Regular Second Appeal No. 93-D of 1957 allowed by Falshaw, C.J. on 17-1-1962, suit dismissed as barred by limitation.
Letters Patent Appeal referred to larger Bench by Division Bench S.S. Dulat and S.K. Kapur, JJ.
In Ex. P-10 dated 25-7-1951, goods stated ready in godown, but respondents replied Ex. D/5 on 30-7-1951 objecting to bill discrepancies and demanding bale numbers.
Ex. P-7 notice specified bales 4193 and 4200, from which 500 yards to be taken against payment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit filed on 19-11-1954 is barred by limitation?
Whether property in the goods passed to the buyer so as to entitle unpaid seller to right of resale under Sections 46(1)(c) and 54(2) of Sale of Goods Act?
Whether limitation under Article 115 Limitation Act commences from date of breach (end July 1951) or from date of resale (20-11-1951)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Cause of action arose only on last resale on 20-11-1951 when damages could be ascertained; suit within 3 years from that date.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 54(2) Sale of Goods Act; Article 115 or 120 Limitation Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Unpaid seller had right to resell under Section 54(2) as goods perishable or lien exercised; injury resulted only on resale.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 46, 54 Sale of Goods Act; Section 24 Limitation Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Goods appropriated unconditionally; property passed to buyer.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit barred by limitation under Article 115; cause of action from refusal to take delivery end July 1951.
Suit for compensation for breach of contract governed by Article 115, not residuary Article 120.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 115 Limitation Act; Soundara Rajan and Co. v. K.P.A.T. Annamalai Nadar

court_reasoning.text: Suit is for compensation for breach of contract; Article 115 applies, limitation from date of breach (end July 1951) when respondents refused delivery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ascertainment of damages separate from cause of action which arises on breach.

court_reasoning.text: Goods unascertained; no unconditional appropriation by seller with buyer's assent; property did not pass to buyer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ex. P-10 and P-7 show no separation of 500 yards; delivery conditional on payment.

court_reasoning.text: No right of resale under Sections 46(1)(c), 54(2) SOGA as property not passed; goods not perishable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence of deterioration or rapid price fall for woolen cloth.

court_reasoning.text: Section 24 Limitation Act inapplicable as breach gave immediate cause of action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Refusal to take delivery was complete breach.

holdings.text: Suit barred by limitation under Article 115 Limitation Act; period of 3 years commenced from end of July 1951.
No right of resale as property in goods did not pass to buyer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Soundara Rajan and Co. v. K.P.A.T. Annamalai Nadar
precedents_cited.relevance: Starting point of limitation under Art 115 is date of refusal to take delivery.

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of David Sassoon and Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Specific appropriation by running numbers passes property.

precedents_cited.case_name: Firm Paharia Mal Ram Sahai v. Birdhi Chand Jain and Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: Implied assent to appropriation when goods removed to lorry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commr. of Income-Tax, Madras v. Mysore Chromite Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Appropriation must be unconditional under S.23 SOGA.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s. Carona Sahu Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Delivery to common carrier may pass property in unascertained goods.
No equitable assignment without specific appropriation.

precedents_cited.case_name: M/s. Eastern Trader Ltd. v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter on S.24 Limitation Act; no general proposition.
Limitation from date of breach, not ascertainment of damages.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines unpaid seller rights including resale only if property passed; no such passing here.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Art 115 governs suit for compensation for breach; 3 years from breach date; S.24 inapplicable.

outcome.summary: Letters Patent Appeal dismissed; judgments of lower courts set aside insofar as they decreed the suit; suit dismissed as barred by limitation under Article 115 Limitation Act.

key_quotes.text: "the ascertainment of the amount to be claimed in a suit for damages for the breach of a contract is something separate and distinct from the occasion of such ascertainment, which is the real cause of action"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing breach date from damage quantification for limitation.

key_quotes.text: "Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies to the suit, and ... limitation began to run from the date on which the breach of the contract was committed by the respondents-defendants i.e. from the end of July, 1951."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on applicable limitation period and starting point.

key_quotes.text: "in the present case, there was no separation or ascertainment of specific 500 yards from the bales. Nor was there any appropriation of such specific 500 yards by the appellant to the contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key finding negating passage of property and resale right.
